author: Darsain SENOU 🦁
text: "Je suis jeune, il est vrai, mais aux âmes bien nées, la valeur n'attend pas le nombre des années"a dit Pierre CorneilleLes jeunes sont souvent perçus comme « tristes, pessimistes, immatures, individualistes, coupés des réalités ».C'est peut-être vrai pour certains. Mais, inversement, il y en a aussi qui se démerdent chaque jour pour sortir du lot, être utiles aux autres. Et personnellement, du haut de mon âge, je suis fier de dire que j'ai déjà accompagné et formé à date, plus de 3000 personnes sur les questions de prises de parole, de leadership,...J'ai travaillé avec des personnes extraordinaires comme : Josiane : ce qui lui a permis de cartonner avec ces 2 conférences pour les femmes en 2022 Aimé : ce qui lui a permis de décrocher une opportunité d'affaires avec l'UEFA Joanni : qui a gagné en confiance, en estime personnelle et pour qui, parler en public est devenu une passion. En moins de 3 semaines, il a su s'exprimer devant + 150 personnes. Jerry : qui a pu s'exprimer avec aisance devant un public d'au moins 50 personnes et qui a kiffé. Régis Houndeton : qui en est ressorti 2e lors d'un concours d'art oratoire... Trophelie : qui a gagné confiance en elle et a bien réussi sa première intervention en public en moins de 2 semaines seulement. 🏆Je suis paru à plusieurs reprises sur les quotidiens "FRATERNITÉ" et "VIF D'AFRIQUE". J'ai eu l'occasion d'impacter également des tas de personnes avec ma voix lors de plusieurs évènements que ce soit à Golden Tulip, au Palais des congrès, à l'université d'Abomey-Calavi, au Togo, ou autres.Donc oui, je suis jeune, mais l'expérience y est déjà. Et rien que mes partages gratuits sur les réseaux sociaux, mes différents accompagnements, formations et interventions publiques le démontrent largement.Et d'ailleurs, si j'ai pris le luxe de me faire rare ces derniers jours sur LinkedIn, c'est parce que, Je travaille depuis quelques jours sur une grosse surprise qui arrive en grande pompe. Vous découvrirez tout lundi prochain. On reste donc au taquet pour ne rien louper dans ce cas🙂.Alors, hâte comme moi de savoir ce que je prépare en cachette ? 😃

author: Carmen Thiam
text: 💫 À toutes les jeunes femmes (et jeunes hommes) qui doutent encore… Le monde a BESOIN de VOUS. 💫 Assez des petites voix qui vous murmurent : 👉🏽 "Tu es trop jeune…" 👉🏽 "Pas encore prête…" 👉🏽 "Pas légitime…" Il est temps de changer la donne.🎤Laissez-moi vous raconter une histoire :✨Il était une fois… Dans un poulailler, un jeune aigle grandissait et chaque jour on lui répétait :  "Tu es une poule. author: Freddy Agbona
text: La plupart des devs intermédiaires que je rencontre sous-estiment complètement leur potentiel.Ils bossent dur, ils font les choses bien…Mais ils ne voient pas à quel point 3 mois bien utilisés peuvent les faire changer de ligue.Je le dis avec confiance, parce que je l’ai vu.Chez moi. Chez mes étudiants.Chez des devs qui partaient avec les mêmes doutes que toi aujourd’hui.Voici ce que tu peux sérieusement débloquer en 90 jours avec de la structure :🔹 Solidifier tes bases techniques pour arrêter de douter à chaque prise de décision🔹 Résoudre des problèmes réels (pas juste suivre des tutos)🔹 Développer des soft skills que peu de devs travaillent (leadership, clarté, communication)🔹 Te repositionner professionnellement (changer de rôle, de tarif, ou de mission)🔹 Reprendre confiance dans ce que tu sais, et surtout dans ce que tu peux encore apprendreEt si je peux te recommander un truc simple à faire dès maintenant :👉 Quand tu codes un module ou une fonctionnalité, pose-toi cette question : “Quelle serait l’architecture la plus claire si d’autres devaient maintenir ça demain ?”Tu verras que rien que ce réflexe te fait passer de l’exécutant au concepteur.Tu penses structure. author: Harish V Krishnan
text: Leadership may be about influence, but true leadership is about multiplication.Imagine walking into an organization where everyone feels they are merely executing someone else's vision:People follow directions but lack initiativeInnovation happens only at the topTeam members compete rather than collaborateIt's no different for organizations today.Most leaders unintentionally create dependencyMost leaders unconsciously hoard opportunitiesMost leaders unknowingly stifle potentialThe greatest leaders understand they are facilitators of greatness.Here are some transformative leadership practices:The Joy of GivingResearch consistently shows those who give time and resources to help colleagues often achieve the greatest success themselves. As Adam Grant explains in his work, success increasingly depends on how we interact with others.Teaching to LearnWhen you teach, you refine your own knowledge. The act of mentoring forces clarity and mastery, benefiting both the mentor and mentee.Genuine GenerosityKeith Ferrazzi, networking expert, emphasizes that valuable networking comes from genuine generosity. It's about making others successful, which opens doors you never imagined.Leadership LegacyWhen leadership focuses on taking care of those in your charge, it creates a culture where everyone thrives.Your goal as a leader isn't personal status, but collective impact.✍️ Your insights can make a difference!♻️ Share this post if it speaks to you, and follow me for more.

author: Ndèye Ndiaye Cissé Lakh
text: Une expérience de courage : Oser faire face à nos manquementsIl vous est sûrement arrivé de vous lancer dans un projet avec enthousiasme et confiance, pour ensuite réaliser que certains paramètres cruciaux avaient été négligés. 📊Les résultats ne sont pas à la hauteur, la compréhension entre les équipes fait défaut, et les attentes ne sont pas satisfaites. Que faire dans cette situation ? 🤔La première réaction pourrait être de chercher des coupables. Mais est-ce vraiment la meilleure approche ?Le véritable leadership exige le courage de :1. Regarder la situation avec objectivité2. Reconnaître nos propres manquements3. Identifier les contrôles qui ont fait défaut4. Admettre que le cadre d'évolution n'était pas clairement défini5. Réaliser que nous n'avons pas accordé assez de temps à la planificationLa vraie solution ? Avoir le courage d'appuyer sur pause, même dans les moments les plus critiques. ⏸️Rassemblez votre équipe, réfléchissez ensemble à la situation. Définissez de nouvelles bases pour finaliser le projet ou, si nécessaire, recommencez sur de nouvelles fondations.Rappelez-vous : le leadership, ce n'est pas être infaillible. C'est avoir le courage d'accepter ses erreurs, d'y faire face, d'y remédier et d'en tirer des leçons. 💪Chaque difficulté surmontée est une compétence de plus dans notre arsenal de leader.Et vous, quelle expérience de dysfonctionnement vous a le plus marqué dans votre carrière ou votre entreprise ? 🗣️Partagez vos histoires. author: Dorit Dor
text: THANK YOU FOR AN UNFORGETTABLE JOURNEY Nearly 30 years ago, I joined a small startup called Check Point Software. We were connecting networks at a time when most of the world’s networks weren’t connected, offering “security” long before it was called cyber.I’m deeply grateful for the opportunity that Check Point—and its visionary founders Gil, Shlomo and Marius — gave me. What began in R&D expanded into product leadership, business development, M&A, and building new business lines. Over the years, I had the privilege of representing Check Point at the World Economic Forum, in the Cyber Threat Alliance, and across countless stages and forums around the world. My decision to leave comes with mixed emotions—leaving behind an extraordinary company and team, yet feeling energized by the next chapter. Check Point has always stood for something bigger: making the world a safer place through deep technical innovation and relentless customer focus. We earned the trust of amazing customers and partners, across industries and geographies. What kept me inspired for three decades was the mission—and the people. From employees to customers and partners, I’ve always made myself accessible, and every direct interaction—every challenge—was a learning moment. Whether it was dealing with adversaries, evolving threats, or emerging technologies, we were constantly anticipating change, realigning strategy, and executing. I always believed that a product isn’t complete when it ships—it’s only successful when it’s used, delivering real value and hopefully even earning a little love. That belief kept me flying across the world, connecting GTM with product, architecture with customer needs, aligning strategy with execution. It was never about my role or title—it was about taking full accountability for every aspect of the company. I felt a deep responsibility for each decision, action, and outcome. And none of it would have been possible without being part of the incredible, committed team, every step of the way. Check Point will always be my second family. I’ll continue supporting the company as an advisor and assisting its success. I am proud to be a Check Point fellow. At the same time, we live in a remarkable (and sometimes crazy) world—where tech transformation is one of the greatest forces for good. I’m fortunate to now explore exciting frontiers in cybersecurity, AI, and quantum technology. Each is like a universe of its own, full of opportunity—and I look forward to help bring impact in all three. To everyone who’s been part of this incredible journey—customers, partners, colleagues past and present—thank you. There are too many of you to name, but please know this is a heartfelt, personal thank you. Check Point is, and will always be, a part of me. I trust the team to continue climbing new heights. With love and appreciation,Dorit Important note: The due date of all this is June and by then we will have a more organized goodbye…

author: Sean McPheat
text: Want a more engaged team? Stop making these 8 mistakes ⬇️A disengaged team isn’t lazy - it’s disconnected.If motivation is low, check for these common engagement killers:🚨 Why Your Team Isn’t Engaged❌ Lack of Recognition – Feeling undervalued leads to disengagement. A simple "thank you" goes a long way.❌ Micromanagement – Constant hovering kills trust. Give them space to own tasks.❌ No Growth Opportunities – Stagnation leads to disengagement. Offer learning and career development.❌ Unclear Expectations – Vague roles create frustration. Set clear goals.❌ Poor Communication – Silence breeds confusion. author: Ole Fredrik Norbye
text: Er du klar for en LinkedIn post som kun formidler forskningskunnskap i tekstformat? Altså - ingen selfie eller karusell. Ingen spørsmål til leseren eller ingen refleksjoner over at livet er sårbart eller at jeg er stolt og ydmyk.  "Zombieledelse" handler er ideer som burde vært døde, men som fortsatt går igjen i organisasjonsliv, utdanning og politikk. Ledelse preges nemlig fortsatt av gamle idéer som er feil, men som likevel styrer hvordan vi tenker, ansetter og utvikler ledere. 🧟‍♂️Her er åtte seigliva myter:1. Ledelse handler om lederen👉 Myten: Lederen er den viktigste, kanskje eneste, drivkraften bak gode resultater.⚠️ Problemet: Dette overser kontekst, relasjoner og gruppedynamikk. Det er sjelden én person alene som skaper suksess. Ledelse er en sosial prosess – ikke en individuell prestasjon.2. Gode ledere er født sånn👉 Myten: Noen har et "lederskapsgén", og det gjør dem naturlig overlegne andre.⚠️ Problemet: Dette fremmer elitisme og fratar andre muligheten til å utvikle seg. Det støtter ideen om at ledelse ikke kan læres – noe forskning motbeviser.3. Store ledere gjør (alltid) X, Y, Z👉 Myten: Hvis du bare kopierer det "store ledere" gjør, blir du selv en god leder.⚠️ Problemet: Dette ignorerer at ledelse er kontekstavhengig. Det finnes ingen magisk oppskrift – det som fungerer ett sted, kan feile et annet.4. Vi kjenner en leder når vi ser en👉 Myten: Ledere er lett gjenkjennelige – de ser ut og oppfører seg på en bestemt måte.⚠️ Problemet: Dette åpner for skadelige stereotyper. Det favoriserer karismatiske, ofte maskuline personer – og undergraver mangfold.5. Ledelse er det samme overalt👉 Myten: En god leder kan lede hvor som helst, når som helst.⚠️ Problemet: Det overser kultur, organisasjonsform og samfunnsmessige forskjeller. Ledelse i et sykehus, en skole eller en startup krever ulike ferdigheter.6. Ledelse er en spesiell ferdighet forbeholdt spesielle folk👉 Myten: Ledere er en slags supermennesker som er hevet over resten.⚠️ Problemet: Dette opprettholder maktstrukturer og hindrer deltakelse og kollektivt eierskap. Ledelse bør være tilgjengelig – og utvikles – hos mange.7. Ledelse er alltid positivt👉 Myten: Så lenge det er "ledelse", er det bra.⚠️ Problemet: Denne ideen gjør at vi unngår å stille kritiske spørsmål om makt, kontroll og undertrykkelse. Ikke all ledelse er god ledelse.8. Folk klarer seg ikke uten ledere👉 Myten: Uten ledere blir det kaos – folk trenger å bli styrt.⚠️ Problemet: Dette undervurderer menneskers kapasitet til samarbeid, selvledelse og kollektiv intelligens. Mange suksessrike team fungerer best med delt lederskap.For mer om dette, sjekk ut artikkelen: Haslam, S. A., Alvesson, M., & Reicher, S. D. (2024). Zombie leadership: Dead ideas that still walk among us. The Leadership Quarterly, 35(3), 101770.

author: Tristan Ebel
text: Ma plus grosse erreur de leadership ? Je l’ai faite dès le premier jour.J’étais fier. Fraîchement promu.Je me suis dit : “Ça y est, c’est mon moment.”Je croyais que devenir manager, c’était enfin être sous les projecteurs.Jusqu’à ce que je comprenne…Le leadership, ce n’est pas briller.C’est faire briller les autres.À partir du moment où tu deviens leader, ton impact ne se mesure plus à ce que tu produis.Il se mesure à ce que ton équipe devient grâce à toi.Tes plus grandes victoires ?Ce ne sont plus les tiennes.Ce sont celles que tu rends possibles chez les autres.Le leadership, ce n’est pas :→ Avoir toujours le dernier mot→ S’approprier les résultats d’un collectif→ Avoir réponse à toutC’est tout l’inverse.C’est :→ Donner la parole à ceux qui doutent encore→ Célébrer les succès même quand ils ne sont pas les tiens→ Créer un cadre où les talents peuvent évoluerLes grands leaders voient le potentiel avant les résultats.Ils te poussent quand tu te retiens.Et te soutiennent quand tu flanches.Tu veux progresser en tant que manager ? Pose ces 2 questions simples à ton équipe :“Quel obstacle puis-je lever pour toi cette semaine ?”“Quelle compétence veux-tu développer en ce moment ?”Et quand quelqu’un doute, rappelle-lui ce qu’il a déjà accompli.Parfois, un simple “je crois en toi” suffit à relancer une trajectoire.Parce qu’en réalité, le leadership, c’est ça :Ce n’est pas être le meilleur de l’équipe. C’est révéler le meilleur chez les autres.

author: Peter F. Gallagher
text: Friday’s Change Reflection Quote - Leadership of Change® - Change Leaders Understand Context Before Acting🎓 Leadership Learning!On April 25, 2022, Elon Musk reached an agreement to acquire Twitter for $44 billion. Finalised on October 27, the transaction marked a pivotal moment in the evolution of digital communication and social media governance. Far more than a corporate deal, it exposed the complex intersection of innovation, influence, and ideology—highlighting the imperative for leaders to understand the environment before initiating bold change. Musk, one of the most prominent entrepreneurs of the 21st century, did not simply purchase a platform—he entered the domain of global discourse, with profound implications for expression, ownership, and technological power. Having become Twitter’s largest shareholder earlier that month with a 9.2% stake, Musk’s unsolicited offer to buy the company was met with scepticism, reflecting a lack of shared understanding between the proposed change and the broader stakeholder context. His public rationale centred on defending free speech and unlocking the platform’s potential by taking it private. The proposal swiftly became a binding agreement, sparking global debates about the influence of billionaires over public dialogue. This acquisition was one of the most controversial in social media history. Never before had a figure with such standing in technology and industry assumed full control of a communications platform so central to global events—from the Arab Spring to modern election campaigns. Twitter’s compact format shaped political and cultural discourse; its transfer into Musk’s hands raised urgent questions around neutrality, moderation, and digital integrity. The turbulent road to acquisition underscored the risks of initiating disruptive change without first fully appreciating contextual complexity. Musk’s initial investment triggered defensive responses from Twitter’s board, including a shareholder rights plan. Legal disputes emerged when Musk attempted to withdraw over bot account concerns. Twitter sued, and ultimately, the deal closed on October 27. Musk entered Twitter headquarters carrying a sink—a gesture that became symbolic of sweeping change. Following the acquisition...✅ Change Leadership Lessons: Elon Musk’s acquisition of Twitter illustrates how high-stakes decision-making must be grounded in deep contextual understanding to guide bold, strategic transformation. Leaders of change must demonstrate strategic persistence when external pressures and legal challenges threaten to derail transformation efforts. They risk causing confusion and instability when acting without a deep understanding of the strategic and organisational landscape in which change will be implemented. Change leaders should prioritise...“Change leadership begins with understanding. Acting without context invites unnecessary resistance; however, a new vision aligned with restructuring shapes legacy.”

author: Dr Lollie Mancey
text: Every single institution has chased performance indicators and KPIs with a fervour that borders on the religious. And in the process, we’ve built systems that prioritise productivity over possibility, measurement over meaning, and replication over imagination.  It’s not that efficiency is bad. But when speed becomes the dominant value, depth becomes a casualty. From boardrooms to classrooms to policy tables, I see a similar question being whispered behind closed doors: Are we heading in the right direction—or just faster in the wrong one?It’s a question that sits differently with each stakeholder :Policymakers worry about regulation lagging behind innovation. Educators feel pressure to prepare students for jobs that may not exist.CEOs are told to embrace AI while quietly fearing they’re sleepwalking into ethical minefields.We’re not lacking intelligence or innovation. What we’re lacking is "consequence literacy" the ability to trace the ripple effects of our decisions, not just across time, but across identity, class, and geography.I often say: culture helps you predict the future. But not in the way a trend report does. Culture reveals what we’re willing to tolerate, what we find beautiful, what we exclude, and what we’re quietly rehearsing. Right now, those seeds are asking us to rethink our systems of value.Because whether you’re a founder, a public servant, a parent, or writing policy, the question is no longer: Can we build it? It’s: Should we? For whom? At what cost?This isn't a manifesto against technology. Quite the opposite. But AI, climate change, bioengineering—these are not just technical challenges. They are societal reckoning points. And we will not solve them with better tools alone.We need radical cultural intelligence.The kind that sees beyond the dominant worldview. The kind that can hold complexity without collapsing into cynicism. The kind that understands that progress without equity is just innovation for the few, paid for by the many.What would it look like if: Corporates were measured not just by profit, but by the long-term integrity of their decisions?Governments funded experimentation in ethical infrastructure the way they fund tech parks? Universities stopped preparing students to "fit in" and started preparing them to change the system? Tech founders had philosophers and poets on their leadership teams as co-designers?I believe in a future where being human together is a design principle, not just a nostalgic ideal. Where rituals, rest, resistance, and imagination are seen as strategic assets. Where the commons are rebuilt, not as a patchwork of policies, but as shared cultural muscle memory.  Make no mistake: the shift from extractive systems to regenerative ones will be messy. It will require grief, humility, and new languages of collaboration. It will need people who can navigate paradox and work across disciplines. It will need us  ... all of us.Impetus. Business Accelerated

text: STUDIJSKO PUTOVANJE U ŠANGAJ Imao sam čast i privilegiju da budem dio studijskog putovanja u organizaciji Mokrogorska, namijenjenog polaznicima programa Bolji Biznis i MEMBA. Destinacija bila je Šangaj, jedan od najbrže rastućih i najfascinantnijih gradova današnjice.Tokom ovog putovanja učestvovali smo na Leadership Module programu na 东华大学, gdje smo zajedno sa kineskim profesorima i studentima analizirali ključne teme kao što su razvoj Kine, poslovanje sa Kinom, liderstvo i marketing.Imali smo priliku da posjetimo neke od najvećih kineskih kompanija poput Yanfeng, Baosteel Group Co. i China Construction Bank (Asia), i doživimo kako funkcionišu kineske korporacije koje pomjeraju industrijske i tehnološke granice.Posebno inspirativna bila je posjeta firmi Labbrand Group, čiji je osnivač i direktor naš čovjek – Vladimir Djurovic. Vladimir je jedan od pionira brendiranja u Kini, a njegova agencija je danas među top 10 brending kompanija u zemlji. Predavanje koje nam je održao bilo je jedno od onih koja zaista otvore oči i prošire pogled na biznis.Organizatori su se pobrinuli i za dodatne sadržaje – poput večere sa srpskim i kineskim privrednicima u Šangaju, što je bila odlična prilika za umrežavanje i razmjenu iskustava.Nezaobilazan dio putovanja bile su i turističke posjete znamenitostima: Yu vrtovi, Oriental Pearl Tower, Muzej Šangaja, Jing’an hram i Zhujiajiao, drevni grad na vodi. Svaki dio priča priču o spoju tradicije i futurizma.Ali ono što će mi ostati najdublje urezano jeste druženje sa 40-ak sjajnih ljudi – vlasnika malih i srednjih preduzeća, menadžera velikih sistema, profesionalaca iz različitih industrija. Spojili su nas energija, znatiželja i želja za iskustvima.Ključna opažanja koja nosim sa sobom:🛸 U poređenju sa evropskim metropolama, Šangaj djeluje kao grad koji je već prošao faze razvoja u koje Evropa tek ulazi.🚗 Električna vozila zvanično čine nešto više od 50%, u praksi djeluje da ih ima i više. Punjači su svuda, dok su benzinske stanice prava rijetkost.🧠 Polaže se veliki fokus na vještačku inteligenciju. 💸 Keš se ne koristi, a bankovne kartice rijetko. Aplikacije AliPay i WeChatPay su dominantna sredstva plaćanja – čak i prosjaci koriste QR kodove.🏎 Brzina donošenja odluka i realizacije projekata je zapanjujuća. Procesi su znatno manje birokratizovani nego u Evropi.🤳🏻 Radna snaga je ambiciozna, obrazovana i digitalno pismena. 🦾 Dugi radni sati, visok intenzitet i kultura „uvijek dostupan“, odudaraju od evropske priče balansa privatnog i poslovnog života.🤴🏼 Prisutan je jak fokus na kupca, brzinu i dostupnost.⛩️ Na Zapadu se često Mao smatra tvorcem moderne Kine, ali istinski otac ove Kine je Deng Sjaoping. Mao se u Kini poštuje više formalno, dok se iskreno uvažavanje daje Dengu.💡 Svaka posjeta Kini donosi nova saznanja i širi vidike, to je iskustvo koje mijenja način razmišljanja.Hvala Mokrogorska na organizaciji i prilici da budem dio ovog nezaboravnog putovanja!

text: You are enough. author: Fondation de la Mer
text: 🚨 Les fonds marins en danger imminent 🚨 Jeudi 24 avril, les États-Unis ont franchi la ligne rouge en contournant officiellement l’Autorité Internationale des Fonds Marins hashtag#AIFM. Donald Trump a signé un hashtag#décret destiné à autoriser l’extraction de minerais sur une large échelle dans la zone économique exclusive américaine, mais surtout dans certaines zones en eaux internationales.⚠️ Par cette signature, les États-Unis remettent clairement en cause l’autorité de l’AIFM sur la Zone (les fonds marins et océaniques et leur sous-sol au-delà des limites de la juridiction nationale). Cette situation, extrêmement préoccupante pour l’avenir des océans, va probablement évoluer dans de brefs délais. Trump souhaitant « accélérer l’examen » des candidatures et « la délivrance de permis d’exploration et d’exploitation » de minéraux dans les eaux internationales et territoriales américaines.The Metals Company, qui souhaite débuter l'exploitation rapidement, a immédiatement réagi à cette signature en affirmant que ce décret « marque le retour du leadership américain » et que « TMC se tient prêt à mettre en œuvre le premier projet d’extraction commerciale de nodules polymétalliques au monde ».🌎 Cette annonce est d’une importance capitale car il pourrait s’agir de la première extraction minière commerciale des fonds marins dans le monde. Si certains États ont octroyé des permis d’exploration dans leurs ZEE, aucun n’a débuté une extraction commerciale.Les ONG et le monde scientifique prônent le temps de la science et la prudence partout dans le monde. En juillet 2024, le gouverneur d’Hawaï a ratifié un texte interdisant toute exploitation dans ses eaux territoriales.Cette annonce des États-Unis montre qu'un hashtag#moratoire est plus que jamais nécessaire.🇫🇷 La Fondation de la Mer soutient la position des 32 pays aujourd’hui engagés contre l’exploitation minière de la Zone, dont la France qui souhaite interdire toute exploitation.➡️ Il faut donc rester vigilant et suivre de très près les prochaines annonces et décisions du gouvernement américain.DGAMPA - Affaires maritimes, pêche et aquaculture Eric BANEL Hervé Berville Assemblée nationale Ministère de l'Europe et des Affaires étrangères International Seabed Authority - Kingston Leticia Carvalho VTA Tassin - Droit international dédié aux mers et océans Deep Sea Conservation Coalition Sustainable Ocean Alliance Ocean & Climate Platform Anne-Sophie Roux Megan Bryce Olivier Poivre d'Arvor Kathryn Matthews Oceana Jeff Watters Ocean ConservancySabine Roux de Bézieux Alexandre Iaschine Elodie Jolivet Axelle Beaussant Anaïs Massé Marie-Antoinette Gallimard Louise Caridi Leseigneur Valériehashtag#fondsmarins hashtag#nodeepseamining hashtag#AIFM📸 crédit : REUTERS/Leah Millis

text: Here’s a clear, knowledgeable explanation of Teamwork that you can use for any purpose:---Teamwork: A Foundation for SuccessWhat is Teamwork?Teamwork means working together as a group to achieve a common goal. It involves cooperation, communication, and coordination among all members. Each person plays an important role, and their efforts are combined to achieve better results than anyone could alone.---Key Features of Good Teamwork1. Clear hashtag#Communication – Team members openly share ideas, feedback, and information.2. Trust and Respect – Everyone values each other's opinions and skills.3. Shared Goals – All members work toward the same objective.4. Defined Roles – Each person knows their responsibility.5. Supportive hashtag#Environment – Members help, motivate, and uplift each other.---Benefits of TeamworkMore Ideas and Innovation – Different perspectives lead to creative solutions.Improved Efficiency – Tasks are completed faster through cooperation.Better Learning – Team members learn from each other’s strengths.Greater Motivation – Working together boosts morale and confidence.Strong Relationships – Teamwork builds trust and lasting professional bonds.---Challenges in TeamworkMiscommunicationConflicts or disagreementsUnequal participationLack of coordinationThese can be overcome with good leadership, regular meetings, and mutual understanding.---ConclusionTeamwork is essential in school, the workplace, sports, and daily life. It teaches us how to cooperate, respect others, and achieve goals together. author: Mohammed H. Al Qahtani
text: From Theory to Impact: What Prince Abdulaziz bin Salman’s Appointment Means for KAUST’s FutureA royal decree has appointed His Royal Highness Prince Abdulaziz bin Salman as Chairman of the Board of Trustees at KAUST (King Abdullah University of Science and Technology).The headline may be administrative — but the real story is strategic.This move signals a deliberate shift: positioning KAUST not just as a research university, but as a national engine for innovation, tightly integrated into Saudi Arabia’s energy transformation.🔅 What’s actually changing?1️⃣ A new philosophy of researchKAUST will prioritize not just generating knowledge, but engineering its applications. With leadership from someone shaping national energy policy, research will align directly with industrial needs — especially in clean energy.2️⃣ A rare intersection of vision and authorityWith the same person setting energy strategy and chairing KAUST’s board, the gap between “what we should research” and “what we must implement” narrows dramatically — a rare advantage in academia.3️⃣ Structural access to applied partnershipsPrince Abdulaziz can activate collaborations with projects like:▪️ NEOM’s green hydrogen initiative▪️ Aramco’s carbon capture facilities▪️ Dumat Al Jandal’s wind energy projectNot just as end users, but as live testbeds for scalable innovation.4️⃣ A repositioning on the global innovation mapKAUST already has world-class capabilities. text: LA DECARBONATION DÉSIRABLEIl y a encore quelques années, la décarbonation industrielle était perçue comme un mal nécessaire : une obligation réglementaire de plus, souvent coûteuse, rarement urgente.Mais les lignes bougent.👍Aujourd’hui, les PME et ETI industrielles en ont pleinement conscience : 9 décideurs sur 10 répondent que la décarbonation est compatible avec leur activité.À l’occasion de ChangeNOW  Les Echos  ont dévoilé les résultats du sondage OpinionWay  pour Equans  sur le sujet.https://lnkd.in/eb8YGfSfVous comprendrez pourquoi un chiffre a retenu mon attention : près de 60 % des dirigeants identifient la décarbonation d’abord comme un marqueur d’image, bien plus qu’un levier de rentabilité immédiate.Et pour cause : la décarbonation est devenue un facteur de différenciation, un levier de relation client durable, mais aussi un atout de recrutement au cœur de la stratégie de marque.Dans un environnement instable et saturé de discours, la marque devient un repère : elle porte un récit, incarne une vision, diffuse des valeurs. C’est elle qui crée de la cohérence, nourrit la réputation, renforce la capacité d’attraction — autant pour les clients que pour les talents.L’engagement climatique, quand il est sincère, envoie un signal fort :– aux clients, qui cherchent à aligner leurs achats sur leurs convictions,– aux jeunes talents et aux collaborateurs, en quête de sens,– aux partenaires, qui scrutent la cohérence des chaînes de valeur.Dans un tissu industriel où l’offre peut sembler interchangeable, le positionnement bas-carbone devient aussi un marqueur de confiance : il crédibilise le récit, solidifie la réputation et distingue ceux qui agissent vraiment.C’est une preuve d’engagement, un levier de différenciation, un facteur clé de compétitivité.On ne parle plus seulement de sobriété énergétique ou d’impératif climatique.On parle d’identité de marque, de culture d’entreprise, de leadership industriel.Ce serait alors la meilleure des nouvelles : cela signifierait que la décarbonation devient un standard — non seulement attendu mais désirable.Un levier collectif d’accélération, au service d’un futur aligné sur nos valeurs les plus fortes.Prêts ?Jérôme Stubler Pierre Hardouin Richard Dujardin Jean-Philippe Loiseau Ana Giros Mark Dirckx

author: Oliver Ramirez G.
text: These could be quietly draining your team’s time.(8 common productivity traps & how to solve them)Work inefficiencies can cripple even the best teams:🚩 Tasks take longer to perform.🚩 Frustrations build up.🚩 People begin to stop caring.The worse part about inefficiencies is thatthey often go unnoticed until something big breaks.Here are 8 common traps and how to solve them:1/ Relying on a ‘Single Expert’ ↳ One person trains everyone on a process ↳ Creates bottlenecks + knowledge gaps💡 Document + record to share knowledge2/ No standard way of doing things ↳ Everyone does the same task differently ↳ Leads to delays, rework, confusion 💡  Map, benchmark, document, align3/ Manual-heavy onboarding ↳ Shadowing, 1:1s, endless presentations ↳ Eats up senior team time💡 Automate; use onboarding tech4/ Projects keep restarting ↳ Leadership changes direction mid-project ↳ Wastes time + drains morale💡Align on success, get buy-in early5/ Messy work environment ↳ Can’t find docs, assets, info ↳ Teams waste hours hunting for basics💡 Organise, standardise, maintain6/ People accept broken processes ↳ “That’s just how we do it” ↳ Innovation stalls, issues repeat💡 Use PDCA to continuously optimise7/ Misaligned team metrics ↳ Teams chase different goals ↳ Creates tension + competing priorities 💡 Align everyone to a few core KPIs8/ Underused software tools ↳ Features ignored or disconnected systems ↳ Manual work stays manual  💡 Train, track adoption, integrateYour team’s productivity is only as strong as the systems you've built.Prioritise removing inefficiencies as you encounter them to set your team for success.Start by auditing and optimising a key process this week.💬 Which inefficiency trap resonated the most?- - -♻️ Repost to help leaders fight inefficiencies at work. ➕ Oliver Ramirez G. for leadership & process improvement.

text: Some leaders leak. Others lead.Which one are you? 👇You’re not frustrated because your team is slow.You’re just:👉 Tired👉 Overstimulated👉 Addicted to urgency👉 And leaking your nervous system all over Slack🧠 Neurofact:When your body perceives threat,your amygdala hijacks your perception.So:“They’re thinking” looks like “They’re stalling.”“They’re focused” looks like “They’re ignoring me.”And boom, you call it "decisiveness."But your team?They feel reactivity, pressure, and your stress leakingvia bullet points and bandwidth.THE TRUTH:You’re not surrounded by slowness.You’re surrounded by people tryingnot to drown in your pace.The 3 Moves for Regulated Leadership1. Audit the Mood You Transmit→ Before you speak, Slack, or delegate...ask:“Am I creating clarity or transferring chaos?”→ If you're agitated or rushing? Pause. Don’t project.2. Name the Nervous System, Not the Narrative→ Instead of “They’re so slow,” try:“I feel urgent. Where’s that coming from?”→ Regulation starts with recognition.3. Build the Pause In→ One breath. One minute. One circuit-breaker.Not for “mindfulness.” To get your prefrontal cortex back online.→ That’s where your real leadership lives.Your urgency isn’t insight.It’s your biology asking for a break.Not for your team, but for you.💬 Do you agree?📮 REPOST to those who need this reminder!*******************************************************🧠 I’m Zora - corporate psychologist & ex-Apple HR🎥 Subscribe to my YouTube (link in my bio)➕ Follow for more posts like this.

text: How I find high intent leads in 2 minutes50+ warm leads a week1. Open up salesnavSalesnav is the single best data source for finding leads. But you have to know how to use the filters correctly.2. Set up your personasThis will save you so much time, save the most common people you prospect to. For examle; Above The Line - Sales Leaders (Seniority = Director or CXO or VP) (Function = Sales or Business Development)3. Input your ICPGo onto “Lead Filters” then input the info of your ideal customers. The more detailed the better, as this will make your messaging more specififc, add filters like:Headcount, company type, location, industry.4. Toggle on “Changed Jobs & Posted on LinkedIn”New leadership has been brought in for change, they spend 75% of their budget i the first 90 days, so go after them!Reach out and how how you can help them hit THEIR personal KPIs in their new role with your solution.5. Toggle on “Connection” or “Connections of” or “Past Colleagues”If you are already connected and know them, you already have established trust so reach out.If you have mutual connections, try and get a warm referral (much higher response rate than cold)If you have worked with them before and know them, use that to your advantage.Look for the warmer leads! Make your life easier.6. Turn on “Save search”This way everytime new leads match your criteria you’ll be updated and notified. You can check this every week to have a bunch of great leads to go after.Name it also so you remember what it is.Would you try this workflow?

text: We don't have the cash to pay a good salary.We're not purposefully stingy. text: What’s the most underrated leadership and management skill today?👉 It’s LISTENING.In a world full of noise and constant distraction, we’re gradually losing our ability to truly hear each other.That’s why in today’s environment; the art of listening has become a superpower.But let’s be real - listening well isn’t easy.Here are some of the HIDDEN CHALLENGES that get in the way: - Preconceptions – We filter what we hear through assumptions and biases. That means we often only absorb what we expect to hear. - Emotional reactions – When we feel triggered, our minds race to respond instead of staying open and receptive. - Internal distractions – Our thoughts wander. We rehearse our replies. We drift. - Impatience – We interrupt. We finish others’ sentences. We focus on what we’ll say next instead of what’s being said now.🎯 The good news? LISTENING IS A SKILL. And like any skill, it can be developed.HERE ARE 4 WAYS TO GET BETTER AT IT: - Ask open questions. Try: “Can you tell me more?” or “How did that feel?”  These invite real dialogue instead of just quick answers. - Maintain eye contact: It shows presence, signals trust and invites people to open up. - Don’t interrupt: Let the speaker finish. It’s harder than it sounds—but it changes everything. - Practice active listening: Reflect back what you’ve heard: “So what you’re saying is…”  This builds clarity, trust, and connection.💬 What do you think?  Does authentic listening make a difference?Jakobhashtag#leadership hashtag#listening hashtag#communication

author: Agata Julia Purzyc
text: Growth needs the right conditions.Like flowers, leaders need support to thrive.Here are 7 key elements for your growth as a leader:1) Clear vision- Define your goals and values- Share your vision with your team- Align everyone’s efforts with the vision2) Strong mentorship- Seek out mentors who inspire you- Learn from their experiences and advice- Build a network of support and guidance3) Continuous learning- Embrace new skills and knowledge- Attend workshops and training sessions- Read books and articles on leadership4) Constructive feedback- Ask for feedback from peers and mentors- Use feedback to improve your skills- Create a culture of open communication5) Resilience- Learn to bounce back from setbacks- Stay focused on your goals despite challenges- Develop a positive mindset to overcome obstacles6) Empowerment of others- Delegate tasks to build trust and confidence- Encourage your team to take ownership of their work- Celebrate their successes to boost morale7) Self-reflection- Take time to reflect on your experiences- Assess your strengths and areas for growth- Set new goals based on your reflectionsLeadership is more than a title. It’s about creating the right environment for growth. Invest in yourself and others.And if you need help - I'm here for you.hashtag#LeadershipByAgata

author: Alvin Huang
text: Low performers aren't the problem.You just haven't unlocked their potential.Everyone loves to talk about accountability,But here's the truth most won't admit ⬇️Performance issues aren't always about the person.Sometimes it's about the environment they're stuck in.Let's imagine an employee - employee X.She showed up with a good attitude.Always listened, tried, stayed consistent - but still underperformed.Then a new leader with real expertise stepped in,And employee X leveled up fast.What changed?Not her. The leadership.Most leaders get this wrong with underperformers...→ They keep them around because they're "loyal" or "great for culture."→ Or they let them go without asking why they struggled.But a skilled leader CAN turn potential into performance.Here's how:1️⃣ Coach with precision↳ Not just feedback, but real development.2️⃣ Set crystal-clear standards↳ No vague goals - everyone knows what 'great' looks like.3️⃣ Hold people accountable with empathy↳ Be both caring and challenging.4️⃣ Aligns strengths to roles↳ Right people in the right seats = right outcomes. So before you cut someone loose, ask yourself:✅ Have they ever had a high-performance manager?✅ Could better leadership unlock what's missing?If yes, and there's still no progress - make the hard call.But don't confuse a people problem with a leadership failure.Great culture doesn’t mean low standards.And great performance doesn’t mean burning people out.Have you ever seen someone transform under the right manager? ⬇️♻️ Repost to help leaders in your network.🔔 Follow Alvin Huang for more content on leadership and people.

author: Luca Senatore
text: 🧍‍♂️Quiet people aren’t sitting out. They’re tuning in.Often, the most powerful voice in the room 💪Not because they speak often.But because when they do, people lean in.👉 I used to think I had to fill every silence👉 That leadership meant always having the answer👉 That influence came from volumeWrong on all counts.𝗚𝗿𝗲𝗮𝘁 𝗹𝗲𝗮𝗱𝗲𝗿𝘀 𝗵𝗮𝘃𝗲 𝗼𝗻𝗲 𝘁𝗵𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗶𝗻 𝗰𝗼𝗺𝗺𝗼𝗻:They listen more than they talk 👂👂👂And the quiet ones?They’re observing 🧐Thinking 🤔Learning 🤓Preparing ⚒🎯 𝗛𝗮𝗿𝗻𝗲𝘀𝘀 𝗾𝘂𝗶𝗲𝘁 𝗶𝗻𝗳𝗹𝘂𝗲𝗻𝗰𝗲 𝗶𝗻 𝗹𝗲𝗮𝗱𝗲𝗿𝘀𝗵𝗶𝗽 & 𝗯𝘂𝘀𝗶𝗻𝗲𝘀𝘀:1️⃣ Speak last in meetings. Let your team shape the conversation before you guide it.-------------------------------------------------------------------------------2️⃣ Ask 2x more questions than you answer. Curiosity builds trust and clarity.-------------------------------------------------------------------------------3️⃣ Use silence as a tool. Don’t rush to fill the gapPause, and let people process.-------------------------------------------------------------------------------4️⃣ Notice what’s not said. Pay attention to body language, tone & energy shifts.-------------------------------------------------------------------------------5️⃣ When you speak, be clear and concise. Quiet doesn’t mean timid — it means deliberate.-------------------------------------------------------------------------------💡 𝗜𝗻𝗳𝗹𝘂𝗲𝗻𝗰𝗲 𝗱𝗼𝗲𝘀𝗻’𝘁 𝗺𝗲𝗮𝗻 𝗹𝗼𝘂𝗱.So if you’re more of a thinker than a talker — good.Lean into that strength. Tune in.And when it’s time to speak… make it count.♻️ Repost to remind someone their voice matters 🔔 Follow Luca Senatore for more on leadership & mindset

author: Gaelle Devins
text: 🌟 Your Friday FLOW@WORK Spark 🌟Every Friday, I share a little inspiration.Here’s today’s spark:"The best insights don’t come from reports—they come from the trenches."Here’s a reflection from my own journey:Spreadsheets, dashboards, and reports are great tools, but let’s be honest—they only tell part of the story. author: Oana Juncu ✨🍓
text: Le dilemme du prisonnier est une expérience définie par le mathématicien Albert Tucker en 1950.C’est un expérimentation  sur la confiance : Un policier propose à deux suspects de se dénoncer réciproquement:➡️ celui qui dénonce l’autre est libre, l’autre prends une peine de prison maximale pour le délit  - comme il est considéré coupable ( par ex. 10 ans) ➡️ si aucun des deux trahi, ils prennent une peine réduite (le doute) - par exemple 1 an➡️ si tous les deux trahissent ils prennent  une peine modérée tous les deux, par exemple 5 ans. Cet exemple est utilisé en général pour montrer le bénéfice de la coopération, mais il est aussi intéressant pour illustrer la vertu de faire confiance .Si on ne se fait pas confiance on est tous plutôt perdants.L’humain a besoin de collaborer pour survivre. La confiance est nécessaire pour collaborer.😳 L’expression « la confiance se gagne » me laisse assez perplexe .  En disant cela on se positionne comme un être supérieur auquel les autres doivent démontrer des choses. C’est une tentative de prise de pouvoir. Alors j’ai envie de retourner cette expression  plutôt en: « La confiance se donne, elle ne se gagne pas ». Faire confiance est une posture managériales assumée et un choix stratégique, pour citer mes amies Carine MAMOU et Stéphanie BECK 🌀 .🌱 Savoir la donner fait travailler la relation avec contrôle et courage. Et c’est un sacré programme.Et vous, faites-vous confiance d’abord ou avez vous besoin de preuves? ——-Si vous ne me connaissez pas, je suis Oana, je mixe des pratiques de Leadership et Business Agile comme un DJ 🎧, et je suis un peu « sorcière 🧙 de transformation systémique d’organisations »  , ancrée dans les relations humaines

author: Fatou Seck Mathon
text: How you lead on Fridays sets the tone for your team.You leave them either empowered or drained for the weekend.These are 4 leadership styles that hurt your team:❌ The Micromanager Monster↳ Wants updates on everything till the last minute.↳ Thinks pressure makes diamonds of people.❌ The Last-Minute Organizer↳ Dumps work on the team at 4 PM on Friday.↳ Creates unnecessary stress and ruins the weekend.❌ The Weekend Hero↳ Sends emails all weekend, unable to let go of control.↳ Demotivates the team and burns everyone out.❌ The Endless Critic↳ Always ends the week with negative feedback.↳ Lowers morale and makes the team dread Fridays.Instead, be this leader:✅ The Friday Resetter↳ Clears all pending approvals by noon.↳ Buffers time for unexpected issues.✅ The Boundary Setter↳ Doesn't drop last-minute surprises.↳ Models work-life balance by respecting the team's time.✅ The Celebrator↳ Wraps up the week by celebrating wins, big and small.↳ Ends the day with positivity and encouragement.✅ The Empowerer↳ Leaves the team with confidence in their abilities.↳ Communicates trust and creates a culture of ownership.Your leadership style defines how your team shows up every day.What kind of leader are you on Fridays?Repost to help a friend be a better leader.Follow Fatou Seck Mathon for more.

author: Chris McClellan
text: Feeling the Heat?... 🔥 It's a common reality for Business Leaders, but burnout doesn't have to be inevitable. Prioritising your well-being isn't a luxury, it's a strategic imperative for long-term success.Here are 3 crucial things Business Leaders should actively do to avoid burnout:1️⃣ 𝗠𝗮𝘀𝘁𝗲𝗿 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗔𝗿𝘁 𝗼𝗳 𝗦𝘁𝗿𝗮𝘁𝗲𝗴𝗶𝗰 𝗗𝗲𝗹𝗲𝗴𝗮𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻: You hired talented people for a reason. Trust them. Learn to delegate tasks and responsibilities effectively, empowering your team and freeing up your bandwidth for high-level strategic thinking. Trying to do everything yourself is a surefire path to being overwhelmed.2️⃣ 𝗦𝗰𝗵𝗲𝗱𝘂𝗹𝗲 𝗡𝗼𝗻-𝗡𝗲𝗴𝗼𝘁𝗶𝗮𝗯𝗹𝗲 "𝗥𝗲𝗰𝗵𝗮𝗿𝗴𝗲" 𝗧𝗶𝗺𝗲: Just like you schedule crucial meetings, block out time in your calendar for rest and rejuvenation. This could be anything from a daily walk, a dedicated hour for focused work without interruptions, or a regular weekend completely disconnected from work. Treat this time as sacred; your productivity and creativity will thank you.3️⃣𝗖𝘂𝗹𝘁𝗶𝘃𝗮𝘁𝗲 𝗦𝘁𝗿𝗼𝗻𝗴 𝗦𝘂𝗽𝗽𝗼𝗿𝘁 𝗦𝘆𝘀𝘁𝗲𝗺𝘀: Leadership can sometimes feel isolating. Actively build and nurture strong relationships with mentors, peers, or even a coach. Having a trusted network to share challenges, gain perspective, and receive support is invaluable in navigating the pressures of leadership.Burnout doesn't signal commitment; it signals unsustainability. By prioritising these three areas, you can lead with greater clarity, resilience, and longevity.

author: Lola Bailey
text: The #1 copywriting tip you’ll learn today(𝘐𝘵 𝘥𝘳𝘢𝘮𝘢𝘵𝘪𝘤𝘢𝘭𝘭𝘺 𝘪𝘮𝘱𝘳𝘰𝘷𝘦𝘥 𝘮𝘺 𝘤𝘰𝘯𝘷𝘦𝘳𝘴𝘪𝘰𝘯𝘴)I picked it up years ago from a brilliant copywriter called Alan Sultanic.It changed how I write sales copy and, more importantly, how I think about objections.Here’s the insight:Most of us try to 'overcome' objections in the sales process.Meet them head on.So:- We prepare counterarguments.- Handle them in FAQs.- Script clever rebuttals for sales calls.But what if there was a better way?This is what Alan shared in his 𝘕𝘰𝘵𝘩𝘪𝘯𝘨 𝘏𝘦𝘭𝘥 𝘉𝘢𝘤𝘬 Facebook group:Shift your mindset from overcoming objections to addressing resistance.3 Key points:1. Objections aren’t always logical. They’re subconscious. They arise when your buyer senses a 𝘭𝘰𝘴𝘴.Specifically, a trade-off that threatens their sense of safety, time, identity, energy or self-worth.2. Every decision comes with trade-offs.The brain scans for:“What do I stand to lose if I say yes?”That’s where objections start.And it’s not always obvious.- Buying a weight loss programme might mean losing spontaneity with food.- Joining a mastermind could mean losing time with your family.3. Your job isn’t to argue the logic.It’s to reframe the loss as a gain.Because every loss comes with a gain, just not always in the form your buyer expects.Examples:→Perceived loss: “𝘐𝘧 𝘐 𝘨𝘦𝘵 𝘷𝘶𝘭𝘯𝘦𝘳𝘢𝘣𝘭𝘦, 𝘐’𝘭𝘭 𝘭𝘰𝘴𝘦 𝘮𝘺 𝘦𝘥𝘨𝘦 𝘰𝘳 𝘳𝘦𝘴𝘱𝘦𝘤𝘵.”→Reframe: “𝘙𝘦𝘢𝘭 𝘴𝘵𝘳𝘦𝘯𝘨𝘵𝘩 𝘪𝘴 𝘢𝘣𝘰𝘶𝘵 𝘣𝘦𝘪𝘯𝘨 𝘢𝘣𝘭𝘦 𝘵𝘰 𝘧𝘢𝘤𝘦 𝘸𝘩𝘢𝘵’𝘴 𝘳𝘦𝘢𝘭, 𝘢𝘯𝘥 𝘭𝘦𝘢𝘥𝘪𝘯𝘨 𝘧𝘳𝘰𝘮 𝘵𝘩𝘦𝘳𝘦.”→Perceived loss: “𝘐’𝘮 𝘯𝘰𝘵 𝘴𝘶𝘳𝘦 𝘐 𝘩𝘢𝘷𝘦 𝘵𝘩𝘦 𝘵𝘪𝘮𝘦.”→Reframe: “𝘛𝘩𝘦 𝘵𝘪𝘮𝘦 𝘺𝘰𝘶 ‘𝘴𝘱𝘦𝘯𝘥’ 𝘩𝘦𝘳𝘦 𝘸𝘪𝘭𝘭 𝘴𝘢𝘷𝘦 𝘺𝘰𝘶 𝘮𝘰𝘯𝘵𝘩𝘴 𝘰𝘧 𝘵𝘳𝘪𝘢𝘭 𝘢𝘯𝘥 𝘦𝘳𝘳𝘰𝘳. 𝘠𝘰𝘶’𝘭𝘭 𝘮𝘢𝘬𝘦 𝘧𝘢𝘴𝘵𝘦𝘳 𝘱𝘳𝘰𝘨𝘳𝘦𝘴𝘴 𝘸𝘪𝘵𝘩 𝘭𝘦𝘴𝘴 𝘰𝘷𝘦𝘳𝘸𝘩𝘦𝘭𝘮.”That’s the psychology of high-converting copy:You don’t push harder. You remove resistance 𝘣𝘦𝘧𝘰𝘳𝘦 it builds.Bottom line:If you want to write copy (or hold sales calls) that feel less like convincing and more like clarity, dig deep to uncover the hidden losses behind every buying decision.Then answer them before your buyer ever asks.That’s how you create conversions without pressure.___________________Hi, I'm LolaI help learning and development consultants build their thought leadership on LinkedIn and beyond.3 ways I can support you:➡Done-for-you thought leadership content/personal branding➡Content consultancy/Power Hour➡CopywritingCheck out my content strategy playbook:https://lnkd.in/eWUce2Dp

author: Sophie Gourion
text: Être manager, c’est apprendre à décevoir.On ne le dit pas souvent comme ça.Mais c’est vrai.On parle de leadership, de posture, de vision.On parle rarement de la solitude feutrée, de l’ingratitude du rôle, de cette impression tenace de prendre les coups des deux côtés.Quand je suis devenue manager, j’ai compris très vite que je ne pourrais plus être aimée de tout le monde.Et que ça allait me coûter.On ne m’avait pas préparée à ça :À faire redescendre des décisions que je n’ai pas prises.À devoir trancher, expliquer, parfois encaisser pour protéger.À courir après le temps. Après les équipes. Après le sentiment de bien faire.On dit souvent que le manager est un maillon fort.Mais en réalité, il est souvent au milieu, là où ça coince.Pas vraiment "au-dessus", jamais totalement "avec".Juste dans cette zone floue où l’on attend beaucoup, mais où l’on comprend peu.Et quand on est une femme, il faut en plus composer avec tout le reste :Ce réflexe de plaire, si profondément ancré.Ce soupçon constant : trop dure, pas assez ferme, trop émotive, pas assez claire.Ce besoin de reconnaissance, parfois confondu avec une faiblesse.Oui, j’ai été une people pleaser.Et parfois, je le suis encore.Je le sens quand on parle dans mon dos.Quand je déçois.Quand je me remets en question trop fort, trop vite.J’apprends encore à m’en détacher.À poser des limites sans culpabiliser.À entendre qu’on n’est pas content — sans me remettre en question entièrement.À tenir mon rôle, sans me renier.Mais certains jours, oui.Ça fait mal.Et ça ne se voit pas.

text: These are NOT real Scrum Master interview questions:- "What is Agile?"- "Define Scrum"- "What's a sprint?"- "List the Scrum events"- "What's your certification?"- "How do you run a daily stand-up?"- "What's the difference between Agile and Scrum?"- "Explain the Scrum roles"Today, these are just SURFACE-LEVEL questions.Companies expect more — it's not textbook definitions or buzzwords they're after.In fact, asking only these things can actually do more harm than good.It can make candidates wonder if you truly understand what makes a great Scrum Master.Modern organizations are looking for something else. author: Christophe Fouquet
text: A year ago, I stepped into the role of ASML’s CEO. I wanted to take a moment today to reflect on the past year.▶ What continues to surprise me after so many years at ASMLThe semiconductor industry’s innovative power and its potential to revolutionize society. The latest example is of course Artificial Intelligence. We’ve just celebrated the 60th anniversary of Moore’s law, our shared pursuit of faster, smaller, cheaper and more energy-efficient chips. Moore’s law and the partnership between the key industry players to realize it remain the foundation of our innovation and the positive impact we can have on society.▶ What I have learnedThe model that we have relied on for many years, the model of global and open collaboration, is being challenged. Our industry is seen as strategic and of national interest, which brings with it new restrictions and possibly even a decoupling of different regions. We can lament and long for the good old days, but the truth is that we need to adapt to the new situation. This is a key leadership challenge – for me personally and for the ASML leadership, but also for business leaders and policy makers in general. It is absolutely critical that our home base, Europe, steps up to the challenge. On a personal note, this past year has reminded me how much I can learn by listening to our people and all our stakeholders – and the positive impact it has when we act on their input.▶ What I am grateful forAll the support from the ASML team, our customers and other key stakeholders. You couldn’t wish for more when stepping into such a role. I’m immensely proud of hashtag#TeamASML, our people and their exceptional talents, their endless creativity and ideas to support the industry for the next decade and beyond.

author: Abhisake Dutta
text: People don’t quit companies. They quit a broken system. I once asked a colleague why they were leaving a job they were great at.Their answer? “I’m tired of feeling unnoticed.”The real reasons behind resignations:1. toxic culture. - The air people breathe at work matters.2. poor leadership. - Micromanagement and favoritism kill morale faster than bad pay.3. zero career growth. - Stagnation is the quickest path to disengagement.4. lack of control. - People want agency over their work, not endless red tape.5. unfair treatment. - Respect and equity are non-negotiable for today’s workforce.6. low recognition. - A simple “thank you” goes a long way.7. poor compensation. - Money isn’t everything, but it’s not nothing either.What leaders can do instead:1) ask your people what’s not working. - Transparency starts with a conversation.2) act on feedback, quickly. - Listening without action is worse than silence.3) invest in career growth. - Build ladders, not walls, for your employees.It’s not about rebuilding your workforce from scratch.It’s about creating a system where people want to stay.Have a wonderful day ♻️.♻️ Repost this to your network if you found it insightful!Follow for more such posts.hashtag#employee hashtag#advice hashtag#tips hashtag#workplace hashtag#workculture hashtag#leadership hashtag#toxicity

text: Retour sur le Club des hashtag#CCE – Intervention de Stéphane Rozès Un éclairage saisissant sur les imaginaires des peuples et leur impact sur la performance des entreprises dans la globalisation.Ce matin, autour de Gilles Bonnenfant et Sophie Sidos -Vicat, les CCE accueillaient Stéphane Rozès, politologue et président de hashtag#Cap, pour une intervention dense et inspirante.Voici un aperçu des 6 convictions clés partagées :1️⃣ Imaginaires & institutions : la puissance d’un pays repose sur leur cohérence.2️⃣ Capital immatériel : l’image d’un pays conditionne ses performances économiques.3️⃣ Entreprise & société : les entreprises s’inscrivent dans l’imaginaire collectif de leur pays.4️⃣ Cohérence stratégique : performance = identité + histoire + leadership + management.5️⃣ Déstabilisation : la globalisation fragilise les imaginaires, surtout en Occident.6️⃣ France : un potentiel sous-exploité, en attente d’une renaissance nationale et européenne.Thèmes abordés🌍 Mondialisation & géopolitique🏛 Institutions & cultures🏢 Identité des entreprises⚙ Transformation des collectifs de travail📉 Tensions entre État, Nation et Europe📈 Scénarios d’avenir : chaos, recivilisation ou contrôle technologique ?Un grand merci à Stéphane Rozès pour cette analyse profonde, nourrie de missions auprès de l’État, de groupes internationaux et de collectivités.Et merci à l’ensemble des participants pour la richesse des échanges !À lire prochainement dans La Revue des CCE.hashtag#CCE hashtag#CommerceExtérieur hashtag#Stratégie hashtag#Entreprise hashtag#Globalisation hashtag#Leadership hashtag#France hashtag#Transformation hashtag#RevueDesCCE hashtag#Rozès

text: “I don’t want to come off as arrogant…” She said it like it was a confession. Quiet. Careful. Almost apologetic.This is someone who's led 5-figure campaigns. Built an agency from scratch. Landed dream clients through referrals alone.But when it came to writing about her work online — She froze.“What if people think I’m showing off?” “What if it sounds like I’m trying too hard?”And I get it. We all carry this fear: → Will they respect me? Or judge me?But here’s what I’ve learned:Staying silent doesn’t make you humble. It makes you forgettable.Let me say it louder — 📌 If you don’t tell your story, someone else will tell a weaker version of it. 📌 If you don’t show your expertise, you’ll keep watching less-experienced voices get picked over you.Because confidence isn’t about being loud. It’s about being clear. About who you are. What you’ve done. And what you can help with.✅ It’s not arrogance to say “I’ve done this before.” ✅ It’s not self-obsession to share wins that could help someone else grow.It’s leadership. And leadership sounds like certainty — not apology.Ever held yourself back just to play it safe? How do you show confidence without sounding rehearsed?Let’s share in the comments.👇 hashtag#LinkedInPersonalBranding hashtag#FreelancerLife hashtag#ContentWriting hashtag#Founders

author: Sorina Manu
text: Hey LinkedIn, let’s talk ''free value''.You’ve heard the mantra:Be generous.Give.Teach.Share.But let’s not pretend there’s no second voice.The one that whispers:“Tell them what—but not how.”“Give, but not too much.”“Save the real stuff for paying clients.”That’s not generosity.That’s performance.That’s gatekeeping, polished up.So here’s the real question:When you give, what space are you in?Generosity rooted in fear isn’t generosity.It’s self-protection.Scarcity.Energetic leakage.“They’ll copy me.”“They’ll take and never pay.”“If I give too much, I’ll lose my edge.”But here’s the truth:From wholeness, giving becomes power.You calibrate your field.You create resonance.You reveal who you are.And your people feel it.They’re not chasing freebies.They’re listening for:⟶ Truth⟶ Embodiment⟶ CongruenceAnd when they feel it, they invest.Not because you held back.Because you gave something real.Because they trust your clarity.Your energy.Your leadership.You don’t lose by giving.You lose by withholding.By filtering.By shrinking into “safe.”This is your reminder:Teach like your legacy depends on it.Because it does.P.S. What part of this landed for you, or maybe didn’t?Drop it below. Let’s talk about the energy behind how we give.

author: Andrew Constable, MBA, BSMP, XPP
text: Making strategy behind closed doors is a prescription for failure.For years, the traditional approach looked like this: The executive team locks itself in a boardroom. They go away on retreat. They come back with a fully formed strategy.But here’s the problem: That method breeds siloed thinking. It limits diverse input. And it disconnects strategy from execution.What happens when strategy is created in isolation?☑ It misses operational realities. ☑ It lacks buy-in from the people who execute it. ☑ It reinforces outdated, top-down leadership models.The fix?1. Involve cross-functional voices in strategic planning. 2. Treat strategy as a living conversation, not a one-time event. 3. Use transparency to build alignment and ownership.The more open your strategy process, the more resilient your outcomes.Because the best ideas don’t always come from the boardroom—they come from the people living the business daily.P.S. text: Who said coaches couldn't invest in sports teams too? 🏀⚽Okay yes—he is a former athlete.And not just any athlete.In December 2024, The Friedkin Group, through the entity Roundhouse Capital Holdings, acquired Everton Football Club from Farhad Moshiri’s Blue Heaven Holdings. 🔵⚪This week, they announced that National Basketball Association (NBA) Hall of Famer and Dallas Mavericks Head Coach Jason Kidd was joining the ownership group.🏆 10-time NBA All-Star and 2011 NBA Champion (with the Mavericks)🥇 Olympic gold medals in 2000 & 2008🧠 Coaching stints with the Brooklyn Nets, Milwaukee Bucks Inc. & Dallas MavericksWhy?Well, Everton Executive Chairman Marc Watts put it best:“𝐴𝑠 𝑜𝑛𝑒 𝑜𝑓 𝑡ℎ𝑒 𝑁𝐵𝐴’𝑠 𝑔𝑟𝑒𝑎𝑡𝑒𝑠𝑡 𝑝𝑙𝑎𝑦𝑒𝑟𝑠 𝑎𝑛𝑑 𝑛𝑜𝑤 𝑎 𝑠𝑢𝑐𝑐𝑒𝑠𝑠𝑓𝑢𝑙 𝑐𝑜𝑎𝑐ℎ, ℎ𝑖𝑠 𝑘𝑛𝑜𝑤𝑙𝑒𝑑𝑔𝑒 𝑎𝑛𝑑 𝑤𝑖𝑛𝑛𝑖𝑛𝑔 𝑚𝑒𝑛𝑡𝑎𝑙𝑖𝑡𝑦 𝑤𝑖𝑙𝑙 𝑏𝑒 𝑎𝑛 𝑖𝑛𝑐𝑟𝑒𝑑𝑖𝑏𝑙𝑒 𝑟𝑒𝑠𝑜𝑢𝑟𝑐𝑒 𝑓𝑜𝑟 𝐸𝑣𝑒𝑟𝑡𝑜𝑛. […] 𝐻𝑒 𝑤𝑖𝑙𝑙 𝑏𝑟𝑖𝑛𝑔 𝑎 𝑑𝑒𝑒𝑝𝑒𝑟 𝑢𝑛𝑑𝑒𝑟𝑠𝑡𝑎𝑛𝑑𝑖𝑛𝑔 𝑜𝑓 ℎ𝑖𝑔ℎ 𝑝𝑒𝑟𝑓𝑜𝑟𝑚𝑎𝑛𝑐𝑒 𝑎𝑠 𝑤𝑒 𝑐𝑜𝑙𝑙𝑒𝑐𝑡𝑖𝑣𝑒𝑙𝑦 𝑠𝑡𝑟𝑖𝑣𝑒 𝑡𝑜 𝑏𝑢𝑖𝑙𝑑 𝑎 𝑏𝑟𝑖𝑔ℎ𝑡𝑒𝑟 𝑓𝑢𝑡𝑢𝑟𝑒 𝑓𝑜𝑟 𝑡ℎ𝑖𝑠 𝑠𝑡𝑜𝑟𝑖𝑒𝑑 𝑐𝑙𝑢𝑏.”Also joining Roundhouse is Christopher Sarofim, Chairman of Fayez Sarofim & Co., bringing nearly 40 years of investment and fund management experience.I firmly believe that sitting alone on a cap table isn’t a sign of strength—it show weakness.True strength lies in surrounding yourself with a diverse range of perspectives and expertise—just as the Friedkins are wisely doing with Everton. 👏Other US athlete investors across English football:🏀 LeBron James – Liverpool Football Club (through Fenway Sports Group)🏈 JJ Watt – Burnley Football Club🏈 Tom Brady – Birmingham City FC ⛳ Jordan Spieth & Justin Thomas – Leeds United (through San Francisco 49ers' 49ers Enterprises)The Friedkins are also putting smart leadership moves are in motion:Angus Kinnear joining as CEO from June 2025 (ex-Leeds, Arsenal, West Ham).Simon Hunter joining as Chief Stadium Commercial Officer (ex-Chelsea) as part of the move into their new 52,888-capacity stadium.Aaron Duckmanton joining as Chief Marketing & Digital Officer (ex-Leeds, Crystal Palace).🔴⚪ Meanwhile in France, AS Cannes (acquired by The Friedkin Group in June 2023) is having a standout season: French Cup semi-finalists & sitting 2nd in the league, with major infrastructure plans led by the great Félicien LABORDE.Kudos to the Friedkins for the incredible work they’re doing to positively transform European football.───────👉 Follow me for (hopefully valuable) insights on sports investing, and check out Achille de Rauglaudre to tap into our Expert Network for strategic, financial, and operational advisory across the sports ecosystem.

author: Ajay Kelkar
text: "Don’t fight the hill," he said. I was halfway up Peddar Road during a half-marathon, legs burning, breath short. That one line—uttered quietly by a stranger—has stayed with me through runs, reviews, even relationships.In this month’s edition of the Leadership Change Lab, I explore something most of us avoid: discomfort.But I’m learning it isn’t one thing. There’s the discomfort of being overloaded. Of not belonging. Of repeating old habits. Of hearing something gentle, but true.In this piece, I return to a moment at Cequity—a project, a teammate, and a senior leader who held up a quiet mirror. I revisit a friend’s comment, one that landed harder than any formal feedback. And I reflect on how our body often knows before we do—tight shoulders, fast talk, a skipped breath.📍I name four discomfort zones I’ve lived through. 📍I share how coachability shows up—not in theory, but in meetings, meals, and mid-run thoughts. 📍And I ask: What if growth doesn’t come from fixing things—but from staying with what feels difficult, just a little longer?This is not a “how to.” It’s a “where I am.” If you’ve felt stuck, reactive, or just a little off-rhythm lately, maybe this will meet you where you are too.Read Part 4 here hashtag#LeadershipLab hashtag#Coachability hashtag#LeadershipInPractice

text: الحمد لله حمداً كثيراً طيباً بكل فخر وامتنان، يشرفني أن أعلن عن حصولي على الجائزة الذهبية ضمن الدورة العاشرة من جائزة الدانة للتميز الوظيفي في هيئة البيئة – أبوظبي.هذا التكريم ليس مجرد إنجاز شخصي، بل هو انعكاس حقيقي لسنوات من العمل الجاد، والإصرار، والتفاني في مجال الاستدامة، وحماية البيئة، وتحقيق التغيير الإيجابي.فوزي بهذه الجائزة يؤكد أن الجهود المبذولة عبر السنوات، بكل ما حملته من تحديات ونمو وتعلم مستمر، قد أثمرت وأحدثت فرقاً ملموساً. وأنا فخور بانتمائي إلى مؤسسة تقدر الابتكار، والمسؤولية البيئية، والتميز المهني.كل الشكر والتقدير لزملائي، ومرشديّ، وقيادة هيئة البيئة – أبوظبي، على دعمهم المتواصل، وحرصهم الدائم على بناء بيئة عمل تحتفي بالجد والاجتهاد.وإلى المزيد من العطاء والإنجازات في مسيرتنا نحو مستقبل أكثر استدامة.I am deeply honoured and humbled to receive the Golden Award as part of the 10th Cycle of the Al Dana Award at the Environment Agency – Abu Dhabi.This recognition is more than just a personal achievement it is a reflection of the dedication, persistence, and commitment that has been poured into years of work focused on sustainability, environmental stewardship, and impactful change.Winning this award reinforces that the efforts invested through challenges, growth, and continuous learning are not only being seen but are also making a difference. author: Flora Castillon
text: 3 public speaking mistakes smart women make (and how to fix them): 1️⃣ Waiting to feel ready.➜ You think you’ll speak up when you finally feel confident.But confidence doesn’t come first.It comes from creating the belief that you are safe, worthy, and allowed to be heardand then doing it while you’re still nervous.2. Over-preparing.➜ You memorise every word. text: 💻 Hier, c’était la Journée des femmes dans l’IT. Mais être une femme dans l’IT, ce n’est pas juste une journée dans l’année. C’est tous les jours. Dans les réunions, les échanges clients, les décisions.Je travaille dans l’IT depuis plus de 3 ans.Je suis jeune. Et je suis une femme.Et parfois, ça m’a fait passer pour moins légitime.Dans un environnement encore très masculin où mes collègues sont en majorité des hommes.Mes clients et mes consultants également.Il m’est arrivé, lors d’entretiens ou avec certains clients, que les sous-entendus et la manière de répondre en disent souvent plus que les mots.Je me suis déjà sentie sous-estimée, comme si, simplement parce que je suis jeune ou une femme, j’étais moins légitime.Mais grâce à l’écoute, au travail acharné et à ma sincérité, j’ai transformé ces premières impressions en relations de confiance.Aujourd’hui, mes clients reconnaissent mon expertise et me font pleinement confiance. Et ça, c’est plus qu’une réussite professionnelle, c’est une victoire personnelle. 💪 Être une femme dans l’IT n’est pas un désavantage.C’est une autre force. Un autre style de leadership.👉 Si tu es une femme dans l’IT, ton parcours m’intéresse.👉 Si tu bosses dans la tech, j’aimerais connaître ton point de vue.Continuons d’en parler. Pas juste une fois par an. Mais tous les jours.hashtag#Adiutum hashtag#technologies hashtag#GirlsInICT hashtag#WomenInIT

text: Tu veux une équipe qui avance ? Fais-la briller.Pas besoin de babyfoot. text: Toxic leadership can poison an entire team. ☠️Let's explore the signs of a toxic leader. 🚩1. Constant Criticism and Negativity: They focus on the negative, demoralizing the team. 😠2. text: 1 + 1 = 3, eller vad säger du? author: Otti Vogt
text: EUROPEAN LEADERS MUST CHOOSE: REVOLUTION BY REASON OR EVOLUTION BY RUIN?In the past 50 years, humanity has unleashed more distractions, disruptions, and upheaval than in the entire span of human evolution. Jean Monnet once suggested that people only accept change when they are faced with disaster. This profound truth speaks to the crossroads we face today—between transformation driven by catastrophe or by wisdom. We stand at the precipice of a future shaped not by reason and conscious evolution, but by ruin if we refuse to act.In Europe, the time has come for leaders to make a critical choice: will you guide the continent through the revolution of reason, or will you allow us to stumble into the abyss of unchecked destruction? The stakes are not merely economic but deeply moral. Leaders cannot remain silent, cannot hide behind a veil of inaction. By doing so, we become co-conspirators in the crime against our planet and future generations.As Paul Polman passionately stated this morning, it's no longer about keeping shareholders happy or protecting short-term profits. It’s about stewardship. True leadership lies in collectively taking care of our ecosystems, our societies, and our collective well-being. This is a fight for the character of Europe—not the share price. We need leaders who will prioritize sustainability over transient gains, who will transform through evolution, not collapse.I'm looking forward to the conversations with Jean-Marc Lieberherr Monnet, Marcello Palazzi, MSc MBA, FRSA, Sandrine Dixson-Declève, Hans Stegeman, HERMAN MULDER, Paolo Di Cesare and many other passionate European leaders here at hashtag#ChangeNOW to shape a coalition of business for good.The world is watching. The future is ours to shape—by reason or by ruin.hashtag#Leadership hashtag#transformation hashtag#Europe hashtag#wisdom

author: Swati Diwakar
text: At the bank the other day, I noticed a man in the SBI queue helping a senior citizen fill out a form, explain the process, and even get the counter moving a little faster. He was not staff. He was just another person waiting in line, probably late for work, but still calm and composed.He was more efficient than the actual staff, and definitely more empathetic.It made me smile, and also think about all the accidental leaders I have seen in cross-functional teams.The ones who take initiative without a job title.The ones who unblock others without being asked.The ones who just make things work.Sometimes, they are buried under layers of hierarchy and unnecessary processes. But they are the real leaders. They lead quietly, with clarity and care.Over the years I have learned to spot them, and more importantly, to trust them.Because leadership does not need force, it needs intention.This moment made me want to start documenting all the leadership journeys I have been lucky to witness and begin a new series:The Accidental Leader: Lessons from Leading Without a LabelIf you have leadership stories of your own, please share them. Let us create a space to acknowledge and encourage those who lead simply by showing up.hashtag#leadershipstories hashtag#swatismusings hashtag#beyondleadership

author: Samia Hasan
text: True leadership torture test: LAY-OFFS!How do you even go about managing the collateral damage from such an upheaval?The question isn’t “How do we move on?”It’s “How do we own what happened and lead from it?”I was recently listening to one of my favorite leadership podcasts, Fixable by Frances Frei and Anne Morriss. Their episode on lay-offs should be mandatory listening for any senior leader.Here’s what stuck with me:Lay-offs are a reflection of leadership gaps — in forecasting, performance management, and culture-building.When a company lets go of its people, leaders shouldn’t distance themselves from the aftermath. They must get closer.Here’s what real leadership looks like in the wake of a lay-off:1. Own the failure. Deep dive into what went wrong. This didn’t “just happen.” What did you miss? What would you do differently?2. Create a change mandate. No corporate talk. A clear, credible, emotionally intelligent plan that signals: we’ve learned, and here’s how we’ll lead better.3. Paint a clear future. Show people where we’re headed. Use data, story, and vision. Help them feel it.4. Mind the emotional gap. You’ve known about this for months. Your people found out today. They're in shock. Meet them there.5. Surface the pain. Name the grief. Name the guilt. Create psychological safety to talk about it — and reward the honesty.6. Act on what you hear. If they ask for breathing space, give it. If they want clarity, provide it. If they want to rebuild trust, earn it.You don’t get to fast-forward through the discomfort — but you do get to choose how you lead through it!👉 If you're leading through layoffs or helping your team process one, let’s talk.

author: Nikki Langman
text: It’s not the big blow-ups that ruin trust.It’s the quiet misalignment no one speaks about.Poor communication doesn’t just slow down projects.It quietly erodes trust, morale, and performance.You won’t always notice it until: Deadlines slip. Tension builds.Top performers check out.And nobody says why.Compare that to a team where communication is dialled in:→ Feedback flows without fear→ People feel safe speaking up→ Collaboration becomes frictionless→ Clarity replaces negative assumptions→ Problems surface early (before they explode)Google found these teams outperform others by 50%.It’s not about having more meetings.It’s about creating psychological safety—where candour is rewarded, not punished.Great communication doesn’t happen by default.It happens by design and a strong intention.And the best leaders don’t wait until things break to build it.–––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––Follow me, Nikki Langman, for unfiltered insightson leadership, communication, & self-mastery.

author: Mosh K.
text: Reflecting on the data within the APS, it's clear that while progress is being made for women broadly—evident in women holding nearly 50% of EL2 roles—the picture is far less hopeful for women from CALD (Culturally and Linguistically Diverse) backgrounds. With only 7.5% representation at this level, the disparity is stark and deeply concerning given our multicultural make up. This signals a systemic issue that is often overlooked in broader gender equality celebrations. When Women's Day comes around and milestones are applauded, the achievements often don’t reflect the lived experiences of all women. For women from CARM (Culturally and Racially Marginalised) communities, this reinforces the need for self-compassion amidst an uneven playing field—especially as diversity remains scarce on senior recruitment assessment panels. Real inclusion means acknowledging these gaps and doing the work to bridge them.
